item.title: Group of Units
item.description: Motivation & Definition Elements in a ring may not be invertible; that is, there may exist $r\in R$ such that $rs\neq1$ or $sr\neq1$ for all $s\in R$ (see here for details). Thus, it is useful to group together the elements that are invertible, which in fact forms a group under multiplication. Definition. The group of units of a ring $R$ is the set $R^\times\coloneqq\l\{u\in R\st(\ex r\in R)ur=1=ru\r\}$ equipped with multiplication. Proof ($R^\times$ is a group).

item.title: Second Countable Space
item.description: Motivation & Definition One way to measure the ‘complexity’ of a topological space is to limit the cardinality of bases thereof, and since the most important cardinal is $\aleph_0$, we make the following Definition. A topological space $X$ is second countable if it admits a countable basis. In the setting of a metrizable space, this limitation is equivalent$^\dagger$ to some others (like, separability, being Lindelöf, and the CCC). In general, however, second countability is stronger than the rest.

item.title: Separable Space
item.description: Motivation & Definition A standard technique from analysis is when establishing a property for some topological space $X$, one first proves it for a dense subset $C\subseteq X$. It is thus useful to prove the existence of ‘nice’ dense sets. The following is singles out a very crude such class of spaces. Definition. A topological space $X$ is said to be separable if it admits a countably dense subset $Q\subseteq X$.

item.title: Hausdorff Space
item.description: Motivation & Definition Let $X$ be a topological space. From the point of view of the topology on $X$, two points are distinguishable iff they can be ‘separated’ by open sets. For instance, if $X$ is discrete, then point are separated, while if $X$ has the trivial topology, then no points are separated. There are different degrees of separation; the most common and useful one is as follows. Definition. A topological space $X$ is Hausdorff if every distinct pair $x,y\in X$ admit disjoint open neighborhoods $U_x,U_y\subseteq X$.

item.title: The Sylow Theorems

The converse is not necessarily true; that is, if $d$ divides $|G|$, there may not be a subgroup $H\substructeq G$ with order $d$. However, that $\Z$ is a UFD motivates us to write $|G|=p^rm$ for some prime $p$ not dividing $m$. Then, it turns out that there is a subgroup $S_p\substructeq G$ with order $p^r$, called a $p$-Sylow subgroup of $G$, and we a lot of control over their existence (Sylow I), their structure (Sylow II), and the number of $p$-Sylow subgroups (Sylow III):

item.title: Subgroup Products
item.description: Let $G$ be a group and consider subgroups $H,K\substructeq G$, whose subgroup product is $$\begin{equation} HK\coloneqq\l\{hk\in G\st h\in H,k\in K\r\}. \end{equation}$$ In general, this need not be a subgroup of $G$. Here, we give sufficient criteria in which this is the case. We also examine when $HK\nsubgrpeq G$ is a normal subgroup. Note, however, that even if $HK\not\substructeq G$, we have $|HK|=|H||K|/|H\cap K|$ if both $H$ and $K$ are finite.

item.title: Cauchy’s Theorem
item.description: Motivation & Statement Let $G$ be a finite group. By Lagrange’s Theorem, every subgroup $H\substructeq G$ must have order dividing $|G|$. The converse is not necessarily true; that is, if $d$ divides $|G|$, there may not be a subgroup $H\substructeq G$ with order $d$. Cauchy’s Theorem can be regarded as a partial converse thereof, stating that if $p$ is a prime divisor of $|G|$, then there is a (cyclic) subgroup $H\substructeq G$ of order $p$.

item.title: Bases for Topologies
item.description: Motivation & Definition Let $X$ be a set. To specify a topology on $X$, one needs to give a complete description of its open sets. In practice, however, specifying a certain subcollection $\mc{B}\subseteq\pow(X)$ will suffice, In which case we say that the topology is generated by $\mc{B}$. Two questions arise: If $\mc{T}$ is a given topology on $X$, what subcollections $\mc{B}\subseteq\mc{T}$ generate $\mc{T}$? What kinds of collections $\mc{B}\subseteq\pow(X)$ can specify some topology $\mc{T}$ on $X$?

item.title: Conjugation Action
item.description: Motivation & Definition Let $G$ be a group. Other than the left-multiplication action of $G$ on itself, there is another fundamental action of $G$: Definition. The conjugation action of $G$ is the action $\phi:G\to\Aut G$ defined by $\phi_g(x)\coloneqq gxg^{-1}$ for all $g,x\in G$. This action provides many fundamental constructions that are intrinsic to $G$. The conjugacy classes of $G$ are the orbits of $\phi$, and we call two elements $x,y\in G$ in the same class conjugate elements.

item.title: Lagrange’s Theorem
item.description: Statement & Proof This classical result is fundamental in finite group theory, since it places limitations on the size a subgroup of a finite group can have. For a subgroup $H\substructeq G$ of $G$, let $[G:H]\coloneqq\l|G/H\r|$ be the index of $H$ in $G$. Theorem (Lagrange). Let $G$ be a finite group. For every subgroup $H\substructeq G$, we have $\l|G\r|=[G:H]\cdot\l|H\r|$. In particular, $\l|H\r|$ divides $\l|G\r|$. Proof.Click to expand... Consider the natural left-multiplication action of $H$ on $G$, for which we have $\Orb_H(g)=Hg$ and $\Stab_H(g)=\l\{e\r\}$ for every $g\in G$, and thus $\l|Hg\r|=\l|H\r|$ by the Orbit Stabilizer Theorem.

item.title: Cayley’s Theorem
item.description: Motivation & Statement Whenever one encounters a type of mathematical object, one should ask if there is an associated ‘representation theorem’. Groups Such a theorem for groups is as follows. Theorem (Cayley). Every group $G$ is a subgroup of a symmetry group. Proof.Click to expand... We show that the left-multiplication action $\phi:G\to\Aut G$ is faithful, for then $G\substructeq\Aut G$. Indeed, if $\phi(g_1)=\phi(g_2)$, then we have $\phi(g_1)g=\phi(g_2)g$ for all $g\in G$. That is, we have $g_1g=g_2g$, so $g_1=g_2$ as desired.

item.title: Equivalence Relation
item.description: Motivation & Definition Oftentimes, we wish to regard two objects as ‘being the same’ (for instance, two sets are ‘the same’ if they have the same cardinality), despite them not being equal. The concept of an equivalence relation can be thought of as a generalization of equality. Definition. Let $X$ be a set. An equivalence relation on $X$ is a (binary) relation $E\subseteq X^2$ subject to the following conditions. (Reflexive). For all $x\in X$, we have $(x,x)\in E$.

item.title: Normal Subgroup
item.description: Motivation & Definition Fix a group $G$ and consider the category $\cat{B}G$ defined$^\dagger$ by $G$. What are the congruences in $\cat{B}G$? In this category, a congruence is an equivalence relation $\sim$ on $G$ that respects the group operation, that is, $g_1\sim g_2$ and $h_1\sim h_2$ implies $g_1h_1\sim g_2h_2$. It turns out that these congruences correspond directly to special subgroups of $G$, namely, the normal ones: Definition. A subgroup $N\substructeq G$ is said to be normal if it is invariant under conjugation by $G$; i.

item.title: Kernel (Group Theory)
item.description: Motivation & Definition A special property of the category of groups is the existence of a zero object; namely, the trivial group $\l\{0\r\}$. Thus, by definition, we have a unique zero morphism $0:G\to\l\{0\r\}\to H$ for each pair $G,H$ of groups. For an arbitrary homomorphism $f:G\to H$, we would like to find some group $K$ that ‘forces’ $f$ to ‘equalize’ with $0$ in a universal way. This can be done in two (dual) ways, called the kernel and cokernel of $f$.

item.title: Subgroup
item.description: Definition and Generation A standard method of studying an object $-$ in this case, a group $G$ $-$ is to analyze other groups that ‘sit inside’ $G$. This is formalized in the following Definition. Let $G$ be a group. A subgroup of $G$ is a subset $H\subseteq G$ equipped with a group structure making the inclusion $H\into G$ a group homomorphism. We write $H\substructeq G$ to indicate that $H$ is a subgroup of $G$.

item.title: Ideal (Ring Theory)
item.description: Motivation & Definition Fix a ring $R$. Its underlying abelian group $G$ admits a notion of congruences, which are equivalence relations $\sim$ on $G$ that respect the group structure, and those correspond exactly to$^\dagger$ normal subgroups of $G$. Since $G$ is abelian, they correspond to all subgroups. However, the presence of the multiplication operation motivates us to consider congruences on $G$ that also respect multiplication, in that $r_1\sim r_2$ and $s_1\sim s_2$ implies $r_1s_1\sim r_2s_2$.

item.title: Ring
item.description: Motivation & Definition The concept of a ring naturally arises when studying the endomorphism group of an abelian group $G$. Indeed, $\End G$ is itself abelian, but more importantly, it has an extra operation of composition. These operations are compatible in the sense below. Definition. A ring is a tuple $(R,+,\cdot,0,1)$ consisting of a monoid $(R,\cdot,1)$ and an abelian group $(R,+,0)$, where the two structures are compatible in the following way: For all $r,s,t\in R$, we have the distributive laws $$\begin{equation} (r+s)\cdot t=r\cdot t+s\cdot t\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \mathit{and}\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ t\cdot(r+s)=t\cdot r+t\cdot s.

item.title: Orbit Stabilizer Theorem
item.description: Statement & Proof Let $G$ be a group acting on a non-empty set $X$. Then $G$ acts on each orbit $\Orb_G(x_0)$ by left-multiplication. More precisely, we have the following Theorem (Orbit-Stabilizer). Let $G$ be a group and let $(X,x_0)$ be a pointed $G$-set. Equipping $G/\Stab_G(x_0)$ with the natural left-multiplication $G$-action, we have a $G$-equivariant bijection $\Orb_G(x_0)\iso G/\Stab_G(x_0)$. Proof.Click to expand... Let $H\coloneqq\Stab_G(x_0)$ and consider the map $f:G\to\Orb_G(x_0):g\mapsto gx_0$. Since $$\begin{equation} f(g_1)=f(g_2)\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \Leftrightarrow\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ g_2^{-1}g_1x_0=x_0\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \Leftrightarrow\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ g_1H=g_2H, \end{equation}$$ we see that $f$ descends$^\dagger$ into an injective map $\widetilde{f}:G/H\to\Orb_G(x_0):gH\mapsto gx_0$.

Such methods can become incredibly sophisticated; for instance, the classification of finite simple groups is one of the major achievements of mathematics. We only touch on the very very basics here.

item.title: Free Group
item.description: Motivation & Definition Fix a set $X$. We would like to ‘canonically’ construct a group $F(X)$ containing $X$ ‘in the most efficient way’. The latter is encoded by a universal property, and the former makes $F:\catset\to\catgrp$ a left-adjoint to the forgetful functor $U:\catgrp\to\catset$. Definition. A free group on $X$ is a group $F(X)$ equipped with a function $j:X\to F(X)$ that is universal in the following sense: For every group $G$ and any function $f:X\to UG$, there is a unique group homomorphism $f’:F(X)\to G$ such that $Ff’\circ j=f$.

item.title: Integers
item.description: The set of integers, denoted $\Z$, appear everywhere in algebra: In group theory, it is the free group on one generator, and is used to construct all cyclic groups, and more generally, all finitely-generated abelian groups. The latter claim follows from the Structure Theorem. In ring theory, it is the initial object in $\catring$, and is the most important example of a PID. In fact, abelian groups are just $\Z$-modules, and rings are just $\Z$-algebras.

item.title: Order
item.description: Motivation & Definition Let $G$ be a group. The order of an element $x\in G$ is the size of its generated cyclic subgroup. A more elementary definition is as follows. Definition. An element $x\in G$ has finite order if $x^n=e$ for some $n>0$; the least such $n$ is the order of $x$, denoted $\ord x$. Otherwise, set $\ord x\coloneqq\infty$, and say that $x$ has infinite order. Proof ($\ord x=|\!\gen{x}|$).Click to expand.

A group $G$ is said to be cyclic if $G=\gen{x}$$^\dagger$ for some $x\in G$. Classification Let $G=\gen{x}$ be cyclic. By definition, $\phi:\Z\to G$ sending $m\mapsto x^m$ is surjective. Depending on the order $n\coloneqq\ord x$ of $x$, $G$ takes on the following forms. If $1\leq n<\infty$, then $\ker\phi=n\Z$ and hence$^\dagger$ $G\iso\Z/n\Z$.

item.title: Group Action
item.description: Motivation & Definition Groups capture $-$ abstractly $-$ the notion of a symmetry. But symmetries are also present in ‘concrete objects’, with different kinds of objects preserving different kinds of structure. The concept of a group action connects the two. Definition. Let $G$ be a group and fix a category $C$. A $G$-action is a functor $\cat{B}G\to C$, which specifies an object $X\in C$ and a homomorphism $\phi:G\to\Aut X$. item.title: Group
item.description: Motivation & Definition The concept of a group was invented to capture the abstract properties of symmetries of geometrical objects (i.e. self-transformations that preserve internal ‘structure’). These transformations must be composable; there must be a transformation that does nothing; and for each transformation, there must be a transformation that undoes it. item.title: Metric Space
item.description: Motivation & Definition Let $X$ be a set. We would like to formalize a notion of ‘distance’ between points $x,x’\in X$, and we do so by abstracting away some basic properties of the Euclidean distance in $\R^n$, and most notably preserving the Triangle Inequality. Definition. Let $X$ be a set. A metric on $X$ is a function $d:X\times X\to\R_{\geq0}$ such that (Positive-definiteness). For all $x,y\in X$, we have $d(x,y)=0$ iff $x=y$.

item.title: Topological Space
item.description: Motivation & Definition Let $X$ be a set. We would like to formalize a notion of ‘closeness’ between two points without necessarily referring to a specific metric, but rather, via certain subsets of $X$ called open sets. One can think of these open sets as specifying ‘proximity’ without necessarily satisfying the triangle inequality. The following definition is motivated by some properties$^\dagger$ of open sets generated by a metric $d$ on $X$, which we now axiomatize.
